<font face="algeria" size="4">**1.Explain the rendering of websites in the browser using a complete block diagram Every block should be explained in your own words.List down all the names of Js engines and their creators.**<br></br> 
<font face="algeria" size="4"> Block Diagram :</font>
<font face="italia" size="3">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,">

<br> -> HTML (Hypertext markup language) is made up of Tags and elements used to design a webpage. whereas css file is part of HTML which makes the page look more attractive with its design ideas look more effective.
<br> -> Parsing means to change the value of one data type to another data type here HTML and css are parsed according to javascript.
<br> -> Attachments- HTML document i.e .js file and .css file is attached or imported in HTML doc for changes.
<br> -> Rendering-A rendering engine is software that draws text and images on the screen. The engine draws structured text from a document (often HTML), and formats it properly based on the given style declarations (often given in CSS).
<br> -> Then final webpage is displayed according to the code.

<br> paint() is a function used to display the effects.
<br> Every browser has **JAVASCRIPT ENGINES** 
<br> three important engines are:-
<br> <li>  CHROME:- v8 engine.
<br> <li> SAFARI :- JS core.
<br> <li> MICROSOFT :- CHAKRA core.
<br></br>


<font face="algeria" size="4">**2.  What is the difference between interpreted and compiled language? Give examples for each.**<br></br> <font face="algeria" size="4"> Interpreted Language:</font>
<font face="italia" size="3"><ol><li>Interpreter reads each statement of code aand then converts directly into intermediate, and executed easily. </li>
<li>They require an interpreter every time they are executed.</li>
<li>It checks code every time means it is executed again and again every time.</li>
<li>as the code is checked every time therefore it is slower than compiler but easy to execute.</li>
<li>It is useful for scripting and other small programs.</li></ol>
<li>Examples:Python,Javascript,Perl,Matlab. </li><br>
<font face="italia" size="4">Compiler Language</font>:
<ol><li>Compiler converts the code int machine level language or machine code directly by compiling the code.
This machine code it is not human readable.</li>
<li>Compiler does not check every statement everytime its takes the code as a single unit therfore compiles and executes as a single statement.</li>
<li>Then the same compiled code it further used .</li>
<li>These compilers are faster than interpreters as they do not check each statement every time.</li>
<li>recompilation is possible for compilers in other pcs.</li>
</ol>
<li>Examples:C,oracle developer,java ,c++,etc...</li>
<br></br>


<font face="algeria" size="4">**3.  What are the different ways of defining a variable? Explain with examples. What is the disadvantage of using var?**<br></br>

<br>=>> Defining a variable is done in 3 following ways:- .

  <li>
  <font size="4">let-</font>
  These variables are most used as their assigned values can be changed further in the code. they arent Global in nature,only define in local scope.. 
  </li>
  <li>
  <font size="4">
  const-
  </font>
  Variable whose value cannot be changed at any point in the program further.initially it must be declared.
  </li>
  <li>
  <font size="4">
  var-
  </font>
  it is same as let variable but it is global in nature, value can be changed throughout the program.It is recommended not to use this variable type.
  </li>

<br>=> Examples are:
<li>let x=7; 
<li>const pi=3.142;
<li>var a=4;
<br>The var is not recommended to be used because it is block scoped like let and const thus can change behaviour at any point of time in the code.

**<br>4.  What are the different types of Scopes in Javascript? Explain with examples each in detail.**
<br></br>
<font size="4">
=> Types of scopes in JavaScript are :-.
</font>
<ol>
<u><li>Global Scope :</u><br>
Any variable decalared outside the block or function is global scope that means it can be accessed from anywhere  in the code.<br>
<br>Example:<br>
let a=10;<br>
function FunctionalScope()<br>
{
  <br>console.log(a);// Local Scope<br>
}<br>
console.log(a); //Global Scope<br>
OUTPUT:<br>
10<br>
10
</li><br>
<li>
<u>Block Scope :</u><br>
Any variable decalred inside function or block is block scope it can only accessed inside the block cant be accessed from outside or anywhere.<br>
<br>Example:<br>
{<br>
var a=1;<br>
let b=2;<br>
}<br>
console.log(a);<br>
console.log(b);<br>
OUTPUT<br>
1 //unexpected behaviour of var.Hence not recommended.<br> 
error<br>
</li><br>
<li>
<u>Funtional Scope :</u><br>
Certain variables are restricted to function where it is declared.<br>
<br>Example:<br>
{<br>
var a=1;<br>
let b=10;<br>}<br>
console.log(a);<br>
function help()<br>{<br>
let a=4;<br>
let b=2;<br>}<br>
console.log(a);<br>
OUTPUT:<br>
1<br>
1 //accesses global scope a=1
</li>
</ol><br></br>

<font face="algeria" size="4">**5.  What are the different types of function? Explain each in detail with example. Explain the working of this in each type.**</font><br> </br>
<br>
=>Types of function are :-</br>
<br><ol><font face="4">
<li><u>Ananomous Funtions : </li><font> 
</u>
<br>
These funtions are not defined with function name and they are assigned to a particular value.
</br>
<br>Example-></br>
<br>
let a=function(var1,var2,...)<br>
{<br>body<br>}<br>
Example:<br>
let a=function()<br>
{<br>
let x=1;<br>
let y=2;<br>
console.log(x);<br>
}<br>
 this can be accessed by using 'this'.
<br>OUTPUT-
<br>1</br>
 <br><font face="4">
<li><u>Arrow Funtions : </li><font> 
</u>

 Arrow funtions are type of anonymous funtions that means anonymous funtions can be written in arrow funtions. they cannot be used in object because of 'this'.
 </br>
 <br>Example->
 <br>class student
 <br>{
<br>college="sies"
<br>constructor(name,age,branch)
<br>{
<br>this.name=name; 
<br>this.age=age;
<br>this.branch=branch;
<br>}
<br>getfullname=() => //Arrow function
<br>{
<br>return this.name;
<br>}
<br>get bio =() =>  //arrow function
<br>{
<br>return this.name;
<br>return this.age;
<br>}
<br>s=new Student("xyz",19,"cs");
<br>console.log(s.getfullname);
<br>console.log(s.getbio);
<br> OUTPUT:
<br> xyz,xyz,19

 <br><font face="4">
<li><u>Regular  Funtions : </li><font> 
</u>

<br> These Functions need a Function name at the time of declaration and they use 'funtion' keyword.<br></br>
 <br>Example->
 <br>function help_GST()
 <br>{
 <br>console.log("hi");
 <br>}
 <br> help_gst();  //function call
 <br> OUTPUT-
 <br>hi
 </br>
 <br></br>
</ol>

<font face="algeria" size="4">**6. What is NodeJS? Explain the event loop with example.**</font><br> </br>

 <ol><li> Node.js uses asynchronous programming,it uses JavaScript on the server.</li>
<li>Node.js can generate dynamic page content.</li>
<li>Node.js can create, open, read, write, delete, and close files on the server
it can collect form data
also can add, delete, modify data in your database.
</li>
<li>Node.js eliminates the waiting, and simply continues with the next request.it runs single-threaded, non-blocking, <u>**asynchronously programming**</u>, which is very memory efficient.
</li>
<li>Runs on various platforms (Windows, Linux, Unix, Mac OS X, etc.),uses JavaScript on the server.
</li></ol>

<br><u> EVENT LOOP:</u></br>
<br> event loop is what allows Node.js to perform non-blocking I/O operations despite the fact that JavaScript is single-threaded by offloading operations to the system kernel whenever possible.

Since most modern kernels are multi-threaded, they can handle multiple operations executing in the background. When one of these operations completes, the kernel tells Node.js so that the appropriate callback may be added to the poll queue to eventually be executed. 
<br> Event Loops order of operations are:
<li>Timers-includes setTimeOut() and setTimeInterval() callbacks.</li>
<li>pending callbacks: executes I/O callbacks for next loop iteration.</li>
<li>idle, prepare: only used internally.</li>
<li> poll: retrieve new I/O events; execute I/O related callbacks .</li>
<li>check: setImmediate() callbacks are invoked here.</li>
<li>close callbacks: some close callbacks, e.g. socket.on('close', ...).</li>
<br></br>

<font face="algeria" size="4">**7. What is Promise? How do you create a promise? Explain with an example.**</font><br> </br>
 <br> The Promise Object represents completion or failure of asynchronous operation.
 It allows you to associate handlers with an asynchronous action's eventual success value or failure reason. This lets asynchronous methods return values like synchronous methods: instead of immediately returning the final value, the asynchronous method returns a promise to supply the value at some point in the future.
 <br>
 <u>**Syntax**</u> =>
 <br>const myFirstPromise = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
 <br>//   resolve(someValue); 
  <br>// or
  <br> //   reject("failure reason"); 
<br>});

<br>EXAMPLE:
<br>let myFirstPromise = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
  <br>
  <br>setTimeout(function()
  <br>{
  <br> resolve("Success!"); 
  <br> }, 250);
  <br>});

<br>myFirstPromise.then((successMessage) => 
<br>{
<br>   // successMessage is whatever we passed in the resolve
<br> console.log("Yay! " + successMessage);
<br>});
